name: Avoid weak encryption algorithm
description: When using the CCCrypt function, you must provide an encryption algorithm. Antiquated encryption algorithms, especially those that use keys of insufficient size, no longer provide sufficient protection for use with sensitive data, as technological advancements have made it computationally feasible to obtain small encryption keys through brute-force in a reasonable amount of time. This rule is compliant with OWASP M5 2016 and with CISQ-OMG ASCSM-CWE-327 recommendation.
output:
This report lists all uses of CCCrypt function call
It provides the following information:
Object full name, number of violations
rationale: Insecure use of cryptography is common in most mobile apps that leverage encryption. There are two fundamental ways that broken cryptography is manifested within mobile apps. First, the mobile app may use a process behind the encryption / decryption that is fundamentally flawed and can be exploited by the adversary to decrypt sensitive data. Second, the mobile app may implement or leverage an encryption / decryption algorithm that is weak in nature and can be directly decrypted by the adversary.
remediation: Better to use the value kCCAlgorithmAES128 instead of kCCAlgorithmDES, kCCAlgorithm3DES, kCCAlgorithmCAST, kCCAlgorithmRC4
remediationSample:
CCCrypt(kCCEncrypt,
        kCCAlgorithmAES128,
        kCCOptionPKCS7Padding,
        key,
        kCCKeySizeAES128, // 128-bit key size
        iv,
        plaintext,
        sizeof(plaintext),
        ciphertext,
        sizeof(ciphertext),
        &numBytesEncrypted);
sample:
CCCrypt(kCCEncrypt,
        kCCAlgorithmDES,
        kCCOptionPKCS7Padding,
        key,
        kCCKeySizeDES, // 64-bit key size
        iv,
        plaintext,
        sizeof(plaintext),
        ciphertext,
        sizeof(ciphertext),
        &numBytesEncrypted);

qualityStandards.name: Broken or Risky Cryptographic Algorithm Usage
Insufficient Cryptography
qualityStandards.description: In order to exploit this weakness, an adversary must successfully return encrypted code or sensitive data to its original unencrypted form due to weak encryption algorithms or flaws within the encryption process.
